column4: I believe the answer is that you don't need to type in the password because you want to access the .deb, you need to type in your password to update the software database and install the software.  So yeah, you need to type in the password regardless of the permissions on the .deb.

Thanks for the reply :) But that wasn't what I was looking for(I think). I want to install nginx in my home directory(apt-get will install it in /usr/bin/ or something) so that I can use nginx in future without having to use sudo

Sorry I misunderstood you.  Looking at the man pages, I'm not sure you can do that.  ISTR that rpm had a parameter to change the installation root but I don't think apt-get install does.  You might be able to get away with changing ownership of the files to you though.
